text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.
Your full name: H.H. LINNEN
Present Address: 3329 Smith St., Regina
Pioneer Address: Francis
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1902

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 18

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? once a month

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days at night? no

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? yes

What time of the day did you go? - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? evening

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? no

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to take potluck used, or was some other expression common?) come out in and have what we get

Potluck may have at times

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? sandwich tea or coffee

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? usually all went

6. Did you ever have "these" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? nut very often Francis

Tell you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "these" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? describe, yes, we had very enjoyable time

Were these more frequent in later years? give dates, yes, held in school

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, a month, etc.? went when invited by a neighbor friend
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many hours were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 18

2. How many of these were bachelor's hours? 6

3. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Max a month

4. Have you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Invited but too busy to go again

5. What time of the day did you go? - In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Evening

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes sir

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had oral conversations? (This is, was the turn to make polite, etc., or was some other expression employed?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Sandwiches or coffee

6. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whilst drives or dances in former summers?

Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates. Yes, held in school

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, a month, etc.? Went when invited, not a regular schedule
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas parties, etc.)

9. Then was your first community hall built?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in houses, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

11. Was there card playing for a prize? What dances were popular? Square, waltz, polka, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school children's own parties, birthday parties, etc.) If you have not described this in your answers to question 7, please do so now.

9. How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

10. When was your first community hall built? How large was it? What material was it made of? Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? On whom did you rely for the building materials? For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for all functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? Town we used both halls - school, Hall for large gatherings.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Pedro, 500, Euchre.

Was there card playing for a prize? What dances were popular? Square, waltz, polka, lots of them.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. Some didn't play and simply ignored the game.
12. That attempt at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visiting treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? (Describe me we all treated often as we would with the treated in early days, not today.)

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Describe any of all.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember; telling or any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular in visiting or social life before motorcycles.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you remember being established in your community?

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS:

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged to your club? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. That attempt at formality or "sawhills," do you remember in small towns such as Oliver and later when calling, calling cards, visiting, treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? I believe we met all treated often as we were used to be treated in early days, not only Fed

13. Was the church known in your community, scarcely any of all

Describe what you remember about churches, telling how often they were attended, any incidents connected with them, etc., if much attended and

in the west, don't agree with the mention of

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember,

telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular

in visiting or social life before now.

We had a few annual ones, but our minutes stated

by auction for church funds but our minutes stated

in and said no, he was to be paid more than $500

and ended each event make as much as they had

expected

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS,

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community?

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

The Wood-Torium Church

I hope you know the reason. Organizing in action

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? If so, tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

About 30 per cent. None not very active

How many women belonged to your

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

Buying and selling grain, fence building,互help themselves

meeting, organizing, entertaining over work, helping

members

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Not in the days after 1914

Then was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it? You asked the question

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your town at the time. State when it was first organized, what its activities were, and purposes it belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in your own relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was concerned in some way with the surrounding community. (These organizations may be connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

What names came up?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? Come in school

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Yes

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Yes

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Yes

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Yes
18. Name any clubs or organizations that were in existence in the town at that time. For each, give its name, purpose, whether it was open to all people only, or to a particular group (e.g., women, young people), whether it included children, and any other information you can recall.

19. Were any religious organizations hold their meetings in school?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-skipping rope, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
23. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? Yes

24. Was there much time for games or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? It was very little work get the other folks, read 9 families.

25. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrows, beads, games or other objects or animals or games in the snow? Describe.

Picnics and Sports.

26. Who organized it? Church group

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? For any one in the district, and we share food a good time

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? Yes

29. If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held? No

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? Bring your own food all sit around my ground

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Sandwiches, cake, cornish, lemonade, water, cool tea.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? Around 2 o'clock

33. What programme (songs) were given by local people only today? That would help funny funny songs
23. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? yes

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as whist? yes

Then, what other indoor games were played? yes

The fun begins family join in such games, or only the children? yes

24. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? yes

It was worth while work for the other people, the old families.

Not that I know of.

PIECES AND SPORTS

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

Church group? yes

26. Who organized it? yes

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school class, Sunday school, or organization, etc.? yes

For any one at all? yes

And we share

Had a good time

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? yes

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? yes

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? yes

Bring your own food. All arrangements my second

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Sandwiches, cake, coffee, etc.

Chicken, meat, etc. Lemonade, water, etc.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? yes

And a program (or songs) that would help local people enjoy (or learn)

Young funny songs
31. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

32. What was the name given to this picnic? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

33. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you know of in the early days, such as the large community picnics, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drinks, when held, etc.

34. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

35. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in them, various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people). Ball games by men

36. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

37. How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger communities, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? 1919

Hockey, skating, I think for curling
31. Describe the features of this plant which you consider as outstanding.

32. How did the plant grow? Was it a weed or an ornamental?

33. What was the plant used for? Was it eaten raw or cooked?

34. Describe any differences in the plant's appearance when grown in different environments.

35. What changes have you noticed in the plant since the first year? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, giving who took part in them.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving dates of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? 1919

Hockey skating: I went for curling
7.

40. What did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? How was responsible for shaping the first sports day? (Use extra sheet if necessary.)

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball, or other teams? Give names and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheet if necessary.)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "traveling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun? To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
40. When did you start your book club? (Give date.)

41. Are there any rules or guidelines for the book club? (Give details.)

42. How many members are in the book club? (Give number.)

43. What kind of books do you read? (Give examples.)

44. How often does the book club meet? (Give frequency.)

45. Do you have any special events planned for the book club? (Give details.)

46. Have you ever attended a book club meeting outside of your community? (Give location and date.)

47. How many books have you read from the book club? (Give total number.)

48. How many books have you recommended to others? (Give total number.)

49. How many books have you given away? (Give total number.)

50. How many books have you donated to charity? (Give total number.)
8.

50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?
   Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contains, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? (Include your press, grain grower guide)

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. We had so much work to do to make a living and get a home together we didn't have much time for reading.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   Who started it?
   In what was it started?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? [Handwritten note: "newspapers and magazines"]

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, additions and deletions, cancellation of subscriptions and added others.

I started free press to take feeder post printed near home. I tried to take the country guide of Pressly's journal from Pleasant, Ontario near where we came from.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen postage of reading material? [Handwritten note: "no"]

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

Nearly all the little [Handwritten note: "no large books"]

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west? If so explain. We had so much work to do to make a living and get a house together we didn't have much time for reading.
9. What musical instruments did you bring with you?

10. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the West? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

11. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

12. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment? In early years in the West? Describe.

13. In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

In the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? How long did it continue? How many were in it? Who was bandmaster? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
Musical Instrumentation

56. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the United States? (List them.)

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home environment in early years? In the recent decades?

59. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

60. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? How long did it continue? Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

61. Was "folk music" or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? How long did it continue? Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. In what was important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrangements, etc.? If so, explain.

Give details of this collection; telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

we used to have a very good apple tree at Thomas and we have won numerous prizes on best collection of butter and home grown, such as raspberries, black currant, white currant, red currant, and also had plumbs but never exhibited.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary)
64. Has anyone from your community been well known or famous in the musical world? List names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music an important one here? Important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arranbales, etc.? If so, explain.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

We used to have a newfangled aquarium, four at times, and we have won numerous prizes on best collection of Butter Black home grown, such as high, medium, straw, brown, black, etc., exhibited at York Fairs also on hens.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer day; not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
